channel.title: Dialogue Puzzle- RuneSource
channel.description:
Been trying on and off for days to figure this out. It's hard to explain that's why i made this video:
Sorry about the link, i can't post a video for some reason.
youtube.com/watch?v=GHwMoUDlAHY

item.title: Dialogue Puzzle- RuneSource
item.dc:creator: @nathanz nathanz
item.description:
@nathanz wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:9, topic:541861”][quote author=nathanz link=topic=660732.msg4417808#msg4417808 date=1396817695]

if it changes when you change the return value of “isInTutorialIslandStage()” then do a search of your source for the name of the function. Then there should be a result, because that is what is changing it…

I have checked the call hierachy… Nothing is called upon this boolean which would affect the dialogues that i know of.

I see you don’t know how to do dialogues correctly, Nathan ;).
-Kids

The dialogues are perfect, it’s the boolean which is the problem.
[/quote]
Did you do a search…? or just say that? because if it is this variable that is changing your outsome. Your computer does not have a mind of its own, it follows a strict set of rules. I guarantee something is calling it. if there is an

[quote]if (isInTutorialStage()) {
do this
}
else {
do this
}[/quote]
there is something affecting it.[/quote]

If i knew where the problem lay, i could fix it. Feel free to have a look yourself if you like.
Add my skype: mrzeus6

Read full topic

if it changes when you change the return value of “isInTutorialIslandStage()” then do a search of your source for the name of the function. Then there should be a result, because that is what is changing it…
[/quote]

I have checked the call hierachy… Nothing is called upon this boolean which would affect the dialogues that i know of.

I see you don’t know how to do dialogues correctly, Nathan ;).
-Kids

The dialogues are perfect, it’s the boolean which is the problem.[/quote]
Did you do a search…? or just say that? because if it is this variable that is changing your outsome. Your computer does not have a mind of its own, it follows a strict set of rules. I guarantee something is calling it. if there is an

if (isInTutorialStage()) { do this } else { do this }
there is something affecting it.

item.title: Dialogue Puzzle- RuneSource
item.dc:creator: @nathanz nathanz
item.description:
@nathanz wrote:

[quote=“matzie, post:4, topic:541861”][quote author=nathanz link=topic=660732.msg4417453#msg4417453 date=1396608748]

This is going with the npc cases that is above the actual switch that then converts to case 1-whatever # you have.

Let me give you some info about using cases.

Example 1:
[spoiler]
This will make all cases 1-4 (or how many) use the functions in case 4…

case 1: case 2: case 3: case 4: //functions here break;[/spoiler]

Example 2:
[spoiler]whereas, this portion of code will have its own thing for each case.

case 1: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case and so on: //functions break;[/spoiler]

What are breaks and why would it matter where I put it?
Take the bottom code as an example:

[spoiler]

[code=java]case 1:
system.out.println(“case 1”);
break;
case 2:
system.out.println(“case 2”); //because the ‘break’ is in case 1, it won’t execute this case and print “case 2”.
break;

case 3:
case 4:
case 5://so for this, case 3, 4 and 5 will print this because ‘break’ is not in case 3 nor 4. If it was then only case 5 will print this code.
system.out.println(“So now every case has its own function and when it executes that function it ‘breaks’ from the case.”);
break;[/code][/spoiler]

If this does not answer your problem, well then you may have learned something about using cases. Idk

Thank you for that, i am well aware of how cases work.

However. The cases are not the problem as everything works perfectly if the boolean in question is returning false.
[/quote]
Could easily tell that was not your problem you have a return statement after each case, which would have the same effect for this code.
Post that class and i may be able to find the problem
EDIT:
did you by chance set them up in the wrong order? Are you by chance trying to do handleDialog(Client, npc, dialogue) rather than handleDialog(client,dialogue npc) ?
i guess im trying to say, did you write the numbers in your switches backwards? Way looks to me is you have a flaw in your dialogue logic… (Obviously) lol. post that method to pasteBin, may beable to find the issue :P[/quote]

You guys are missing the point, when the boolean is returning false it is fine but when it is returning true it causes this problem. It is triggering something somewhere but i just can’t find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Dialogue Puzzle- RuneSource
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“nathanz, post:3, topic:541861”][quote author=Bl3nd link=topic=660732.msg4417420#msg4417420 date=1396574665]
This is going with the npc cases that is above the actual switch that then converts to case 1-whatever # you have.

Let me give you some info about using cases.

Example 1:
[spoiler]
This will make all cases 1-4 (or how many) use the functions in case 4…

case 1: case 2: case 3: case 4: //functions here break;[/spoiler]

Example 2:
[spoiler]whereas, this portion of code will have its own thing for each case.

case 1: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case and so on: //functions break;[/spoiler]

What are breaks and why would it matter where I put it?
Take the bottom code as an example:

[spoiler]

[code=java]case 1:
system.out.println(“case 1”);
break;
case 2:
system.out.println(“case 2”); //because the ‘break’ is in case 1, it won’t execute this case and print “case 2”.
break;

case 3:
case 4:
case 5://so for this, case 3, 4 and 5 will print this because ‘break’ is not in case 3 nor 4. If it was then only case 5 will print this code.
system.out.println(“So now every case has its own function and when it executes that function it ‘breaks’ from the case.”);
break;[/code][/spoiler]

If this does not answer your problem, well then you may have learned something about using cases. Idk
[/quote]

Thank you for that, i am well aware of how cases work.

However. The cases are not the problem as everything works perfectly if the boolean in question is returning false.[/quote]
Could easily tell that was not your problem you have a return statement after each case, which would have the same effect for this code.
Post that class and i may be able to find the problem
EDIT:
did you by chance set them up in the wrong order? Are you by chance trying to do handleDialog(Client, npc, dialogue) rather than handleDialog(client,dialogue npc) ?
i guess im trying to say, did you write the numbers in your switches backwards? Way looks to me is you have a flaw in your dialogue logic… (Obviously) lol. post that method to pasteBin, may beable to find the issue

Read full topic

item.title: Dialogue Puzzle- RuneSource
item.dc:creator: @nathanz nathanz
item.description:
@nathanz wrote:

[quote=“Bl3nd, post:2, topic:541861”]This is going with the npc cases that is above the actual switch that then converts to case 1-whatever # you have.

Let me give you some info about using cases.

Example 1:
[spoiler]
This will make all cases 1-4 (or how many) use the functions in case 4…

case 1: case 2: case 3: case 4: //functions here break;[/spoiler]

Example 2:
[spoiler]whereas, this portion of code will have its own thing for each case.

case 1: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case 2: //functions break; case and so on: //functions break;[/spoiler]

What are breaks and why would it matter where I put it?
Take the bottom code as an example:

[spoiler]

[code=java]case 1:
system.out.println(“case 1”);
break;
case 2:
system.out.println(“case 2”); //because the ‘break’ is in case 1, it won’t execute this case and print “case 2”.
break;

case 3:
case 4:
case 5://so for this, case 3, 4 and 5 will print this because ‘break’ is not in case 3 nor 4. If it was then only case 5 will print this code.
system.out.println(“So now every case has its own function and when it executes that function it ‘breaks’ from the case.”);
break;[/code][/spoiler]

If this does not answer your problem, well then you may have learned something about using cases. Idk :P[/quote]

Thank you for that, i am well aware of how cases work.

However. The cases are not the problem as everything works perfectly if the boolean in question is returning false.

Read full topic
